Assessments.ResultHint: You have completed this assessment. Print this page, then proceed for feedback.
Assessments.ResultHint_1: Print your feedback form for your records, then click Continue to return to the Menu.

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify sources of error that can be encountered in bacteriological sampling/analysis that can cause false positives.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Collecting Air Samples and Use of Direct Reading Instuments (DRIs)
Question.STS_Line: • 4.15.3.11 Collect potable water samples
Question.Training_Reference:
• BE Field Manual
  • Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater
  • USAFSAM Laboratory Sampling Guide
Question.QuestionText: In order to prevent a false positive sample, put the steps for collecting a water sample using a 100ml bottle for bacteriological analysis from a tap source in the correct order.
Question.InstructionText: Drag the letters to the appropriate numbered locations, then click Done.

Options.Option: Fill bottle to 100ml line, leave air space, recap bottle
Select a fixed (non-swivel) cold water faucet
Flush for 3 minutes at high velocity
Slow water flow to a trickle

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify chemical agents that can be detected using the M-272 water test kit.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Limitations and Uses of Equipment and PPE
Question.STS_Line: • 4.15.3.5 Water sampling devices
Question.Training_Reference: • Technical Manual 3-6665-319-10, M272 Chemical Agent Water Test Kit
Question.QuestionText: Which of the following can NOT be detected using the M-272 water test kit?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Question.CompentancyDescription: Understand the purpose of performing OEHSA.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Performing OEHSA and Preventive Measures
Question.STS_Line: • 4.1.2 OEHSA
Question.Training_Reference:
• AFMAN 48-154, Occupational and Environmental Health Site Assessment
  • OEHSA Documentation and Data Management Technical Guide
Question.QuestionText: Which of the following best describes the purpose of performing OEHSA?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Options.Option: To assess the susceptibility of food and water, including ice and bottled water supplies, to natural or intentional contamination or destruction
To identify hazardous exposure agents with complete or potentially complete exposure pathways that may affect the health of deployed personnel
To assess individual exposures to various substances, especially harmful chemicals, by measuring the parent compound in biological media
To monitor biological specimens for changes resulting from exposure to materials foreign to the body or detect parent compounds or metabolites

Question.CompentancyDescription: Describe signs/symptoms of thermal stress (heat/cold).
Question.CompentancyTopic: Threat and Symptom Assessment
Question.STS_Line: • 4.12.2 Thermal stress hazards
Question.Training_Reference: • AFPAM 48-151, Thermal Injury
Question.QuestionText: Match the signs and symptoms of thermal stress.
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Question.CompentancyDescription: State the factors that affect permeation.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Threat and Symptom Assessment
Question.STS_Line: • 4.1.12 Use, selection and limitations of PPE
Question.Training_Reference:
• OSHA Technical Manual, Section VIII, Chapter 1, Protective Clothing
  • Quick Selection Guide to Chemical Protective Clothing
Question.QuestionText: Determine whether each statement about permeation is true or false.
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Options.Option: Solids and high-viscosity liquids tend to permeate more readily than gases, vapors, and low-viscosity liquids
Heat generally decreases the permeation rate of contaminants
Higher contaminant concentration in the area increases potential for permeation
The longer a contaminant is in contact with an object, the greater the probability and extent of permeation

Question.CompentancyDescription: Define when air sampling is needed.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Collecting Air Samples and Use of Direct Reading Instuments (DRIs)
Question.STS_Line:
• 4.5.2.2 Air sampling devices
  • 4.5.2.4 Establish air sampling strategies
  • 4.5.2.6.3 Portable GC-MS (e.g., HAPSITE)
Question.Training_Reference:
• Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
  • HAPSITE User's Manual
  • NIOSH Publication 77-173, Occupational Exposure Sampling Strategy Manual
Question.QuestionText: Under which one of the following situations would a HAPSITE NOT be used for air sampling?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Options.Option: When agent concentrations are below the threshold limits for an M256 kit
To verify a suspected false alarm indication on standard chemical detection equipment

Question.QuestionText: Select the instruments below that are used to detect gases and vapors.
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Question.CompentancyDescription: Recognize purpose of collecting air samples using Direct Reading Instruments (DRIs).
Question.CompentancyTopic: Collecting Air Samples and Use of Direct Reading Instuments (DRIs)
Question.STS_Line: • 4.5.2.2 Air sampling devices
Question.Training_Reference:
• AIHA, The Occupational Environment: Its Evaluation, Control and Management
  • Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
Question.QuestionText: Which statement about Direct Reading Instruments is true?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Options.Option: All direct reading instruments indicate concentration of the substance as an instantaneous concentration and as a TWA
Direct reading instruments enable a technician to decide if he/she needs to accomplish confirmatory sampling
For a proper direct reading, several samples must be taken to be useful (usually 6-10 samples)
Direct reading instrument results often require lab interpretation

then click Done.

Quality Assurance and Quality Control Plan

Question.QuestionText: Which two of the following statements represent limitations of Level D protective equipment?
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Options.Option: This level can only be worn in the hot zone
The atmosphere must contain at least 19.5% oxygen if this level is worn
This level is not acceptable for Chemical Emergency Response
This level cannot be worn when the chemical concentration is less than the IDLH level

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify the relationship between water vulnerability assessments, sanitary surveys, and aircraft watering point surveys.

  • AFIOH Water Vulnerability and Risk Assessments for Potable Water Assets
Question.QuestionText: Match the type of water analysis with its purpose.
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Options.Option: To identify areas in a water distribution system that are susceptible to tampering, sabotage, and contamination
To perform analysis of facilities and/or equipment used to transfer water such as trucks, hoses, hydrants, faucets, and buckets
To evaluate the adequacy of the water source and facilities of a public water system for producing and distributing safe drinking water

option_titles.option_title: Aircraft Watering Point Survey

Question.CompentancyDescription: Recall guidance provided in the USAFSAM Laboratory Sampling Guide.
Question.STS_Line: • 4.5.1.2 OEH sample guide (include USAPHC guide)
Question.Training_Reference: • USAFSAM Laboratory Sampling Guide
Question.QuestionText: Upon receipt of air sampling results from the laboratory, which two of the following corrections are required for media blanks?
Question.InstructionText:
Select all that apply,
then click Done.

Options.Option: Average the reported levels on media blanks and field blanks, and then correct your field samples.
No corrections are required; the laboratory blank corrects when contaminants are detected on media blanks.
Average the reported levels on media blanks above the laboratory’s reporting limit and correct your field samples.
No corrections are required if media blanks have reported concentrations below the laboratory’s reporting limit.

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify the proper sample preparation and preservation methods.
Question.STS_Line:
• 4.5.1.2 OEH sample guide (include USAPHC guide)
  • 4.5.1.3 Prepare and/or preserve samples for shipment
Question.Training_Reference: • USAFSAM Laboratory Sampling Guide
Question.QuestionText: Match the type of surface and ground water sample with the appropriate container size and preservative.
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify basic facts and terms related to backflow prevention and cross-connection hazard classification.
Question.STS_Line: • 4.15.1.10 Health risk ratings for backflow or cross connection areas
Question.Training_Reference: • USAFSAM Drinking Water Surveillance Technical Guide
Question.QuestionText: Which of the following best defines a high hazard regarding cross-connections?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Options.Option: Does not create a significant hazard to the public health
Pollution is an impairment of the quality of the potable water
May spread disease by sewage, industrial fluids, or chemicals
Adversely affects the aesthetic quality of potable water for potable use

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify characteristics of total exposure health threat evaluation.
Question.STS_Line:
• 3.2.1 Solve calculations using basic arithmetic functions (add, subtract, multiply, and divide whole numbers, fractions, and decimals)
  • 4.1.2.5 Total exposure health risk (additive, synergistic, multiple routes, etc.)
Question.Training_Reference:
• 29 CFR 1910.1000(d)(2)(i)
  • Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
  • AIHA, A Strategy for Assessing and Managing Occupational Exposures
Question.QuestionText: Personnel are exposed to a chemical containing air contaminants which act upon the body organ systems listed in the table below. Given air sampling results and the Occupational and Environmental Exposure Limit (OEEL), which of the following best defines the exposure?
Question.InstructionText: Select the correct answer, then click Done.

Options.Option: Overexposure, equivalent exposure is 1.1 and exceeds unity (1)
Overexposure, equivalent exposure is 1.5 and exceeds unity (1)
No overexposure, equivalent exposure is 0.527 and does not exceed unity (1)
No overexposure, equivalent exposure is 0.98 and does not exceed unity (1)

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify considerations in determining and evaluating occupational and environmental health controls.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Threat Assessment and Decontamination
Question.STS_Line: • 4.1.2.6 OEH exposure controls
Question.Training_Reference: • AFMAN 48-155, Occupational and Environmental Health Exposure Controls
Question.QuestionText: The effectiveness of occupational and environmental health controls must be routinely evaluated. The frequency of the control evaluation should be based on which two of the following factors?
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Options.Option: Frequency and duration of chemical used in a controlled industrial area
Risk to personnel if performance of control degrades or fails

Whether the control was implemented for an immediate or
long-term environmental threat

Question.QuestionText: Which two of the following are TRUE regarding the Reverse Osmosis Water Purification Unit (ROWPU)?
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Options.Option: Acts as a disinfectant to kill bacteria
Can turn salt water into potable water
Tests for chemical agents including cyanide and lewisite
Uses a semi-permeable membrane to filter contaminants

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify characteristics of total exposure health threat evaluation.
Question.STS_Line:
• 3.2.1 Solve calculations using basic arithmetic functions (add, subtract, multiply, and divide whole numbers, fractions, and decimals)
  • 4.1.2.5 Total exposure health risk (additive, synergistic, multiple routes, etc.)
Question.Training_Reference:
• 29 CFR 1910.1000(d)(2)(i)
  • Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
  • AIHA, A Strategy for Assessing and Managing Occupational Exposures
Question.QuestionText: Which two of the following statements are true regarding the evaluation of total exposure health threats?
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Options.Option: Dermal exposures should be systematically assessed in conjunction with airborne and other exposure assessments.
Dermal sampling is an effective method for determining the effectiveness of controls and quantifying skin exposures.
When two or more hazardous substances that act upon the same body organ system are present, the effects of the individual components should be given primary consideration.
While air monitoring measures the composition of the external environment surrounding the worker, biological monitoring measures the amount of chemical absorbed into the body.

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify considerations in determining and evaluating occupational and environmental health controls.
Question.STS_Line: • 4.1.2.6 OEH exposure controls
Question.Training_Reference: • AFMAN 48-155, Occupational and Environmental Health Exposure Controls
Question.QuestionText: Determine whether the following parameters are true or false regarding the assessment of an OEH control’s effectiveness.
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Options.Option: The control must always be considered according to the following priority: engineering, administrative, and personal protective equipment.
The control must be able to mitigate the OEH threat exposure to below the established, recognized OEEL.
The control must be practical when considering cost and time associated with implementation.
The responsible organization must be able to reasonably implement the control option.
The health risk associated with the OEH threat must be mitigated using an engineering control.
